title: Can an electric car's battery be charged by receiving a shot of lightning? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not a chance. You can’t tap just a tiny amount of lightning. The amount of electron flow, i.e., energy, in even the smallest lighting bolt would overheat a car battery instantaneously. It would simply explode, with enough force to shatter your car into fragments and scatter them over several acres of ground. If you were anywhere in the vicinity, you would be cooked into a cinder, even before the debris from your exploding car would rip what is left of your body into shreds.
That’s the only way the flux capacitor can get 1.21 Gigawatts. Actually the battery probably could not handle such a huge surge of electricity all at once. I wonder if it were possible, and how.
another way to charge up your battery is by getting of the highway and going on a road without using your brakes. until you reach the speed limit of that road which should be 30 mph.
Of course not. A lightning bolt has millions of volts. A direct strike on a battery would blow it into little pieces.
More likely a lightning strike will cause serious damage! Batteries and electronics do not well receive super high voltage well.
